This leaves it mostly to S&P. I see the following arguments for a downgrade:
- Italy's budget deficit is increasing, economcy will most likely contract substantially in 2020
- concerns about Italy's financial position have increased over recent years and last rating change by S&P is already 2.5 years back
- moving to BBB- would likely not increase pressure on Italy too much as still investment rating and just confirm Moody's stance
- UK's debt downgrade by Fitch to AA- on 28 March shows that rating agencies are taking into account the Coronavirus impact aleady (https://www.ft.com/content/28fbd0d1-c5be-4a8b-8c63-b14c746ee8bc) Against downgrade:
- Affirmation of France rating at AA by S&P on 04 April, outlook remains stable (https://in.reuters.com/article/brief-sp-says-france-aa-a-1-ratings-affi/brief-sp-says-france-aa-a-1-ratings-affirmed-outlook-stable-idINFWN2BR1BO) despite France's growing budget deficit (4.3% of GDP) and expected economic contraction of 1.7% for 2020; this is an example how a (currently assumed as) temporary slowdown usually does not affect ratings
- this is underlined by a BIS study (https://www.bis.org/publ/work207.pdf): "Rating decisions are typically not influenced by events whose impact on credit quality is expected to be temporary, such as a slowdown in economic growth" and "In  a  random  sample  of  30  downgrades  over  the  2001-04  period,  we  find  that  only  10%  make  reference  to  new  developments;  the  remainder  relate  to  longer-term  financial  trends  or  previously  released  information"

Ok, so first let's set the scene. The current ratings from the 3 credit rating agencies for Italy are as follows:
S&P: BBB (negative outlook) 
Moody's: Baa3 (stable outlook)
Fitch: BBB (negative outlook)
So S&P and Fitch both rate Italy two notches above sub-investment grade (or junk) with a negative outlook, while Moody's have them a notch lower. The risk of a downgrade therefore seems much more likely to come from S&P and Fitch. S&P will review their rating on Italy on April 24th, Moody's will do so on 8th May and Fitch on July 10th. While rating changes do occur outside these windows, it is rare. Therefore we should focus on S&P. If we go back to the 26th April 2019 rating action (available on S&P's website), where the BBB rating was reaffirmed, S&P gave 3 reasons that would potentially lead to them downgrading Italy:
"1. General government deficits and net government debt as a percentage of GDP significantly exceed our forecasts; or
2. We observe a marked deterioration in external financial conditions for Italy's government and its banks; or
3. Policy changes permanently weaken Italy's potential growth." Both the deficit and debt/gdp have increased significantly due to the government response to COVID-19 (https://www.reuters.com/article/italy-ratings-scope/update-1-italys-debt-to-gdp-could-easily-top-145-scope-ratings-idUSL8N2BJ8MH). The question is whether this is a temporary step-up or the start of a trend. If only temporary, is it enough for the CRA's to downgrade them? 2. Italian bond yields have remained under control due to the ECB's €750bn pandemic emergency purchase program (https://www.investing.com/rates-bonds/italy-10-year-bond-yield). This should prevent external financing conditions from deteriorating. 3. There have been few meaningful long-term policy changes so not overly worried about this. Probably more importantly, a S&P bigwig recently said that Italy's sovereign credit rating would only be hit if the coronavirus hits LONG-TERM growth (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-ratings-s-p/sp-global-risk-to-italy-rating-only-if-coronavirus-hits-long-term-growth-idUSKBN20X213). To me this says they are not imminently planning a downgrade. So to summarise:
S&P may have reason to downgrade Italy given the increase in the deficit and debt/gdp ratio, but comments from them suggest they the current situation may only be a temporary hit and not enough to warrant a downgrade (I may be reading too much into this). I give them a 25% chance of downgrading Italy before 4th July.
Moody's are very unlikely to downgrade Italy to junk, especially without moving to a negative outlook first. <1% chance of a downgrade before 4th July.
Fitch are in a similar bucket to S&P, but they are not scheduled to review Italy until July 10th (maybe an error in the way the question is phrased??). Therefore I only give them a 5% chance of downgrading Italy before 4th July. That brings us to an overall probability of 25% + 5% - (25%*5%) = 28.75%
